p: Additionally, human habitation to na√Øve environments increases the frequency of wildlife consumption and trading and thereby, changing the human-animal interfaces which potentiate the emergence/reemergence of zoonotic diseases and their spread via global wildlife markets [ 21, [82], [83], [84], [85]]. Even then, as in ebola, patterns of EIDs are highly contextual and variable regionally and locally due to divergent and dynamic economic, ecological, and sociopolitical reasons.
